Metadata.Title: SSL Is Required for All Private Pages
Metadata.DirectLink: SSL Is Required for All Private Pages

Content.Data:
Applies To

  • ASP.NET 4.0

What to Check For

Verify that SSL is required for all private pages.

Why

SSL should be used to protect all pages that handle sensitive data, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features, to prevent unauthorized information disclosure.

How To Check

To verify that SSL is required for all private pages:

  1. Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

  2. Verify that a HTTPS binding exists. Start the "Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager". Right-click on the site and select "Edit bindings...". Verify that a HTTPS binding exists. The HTTPS protocol should be bound to port 443.

  3. Check that SSL is required for all sensitive pages. Start the "Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager". Navigate the folders with the sensitive pages. Double-click on the SSL icon in the right pane and make sure that SSL is enabled for the folder.

How To Fix

To enable SSL on all sensitive pages:

  1. Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

  2. Enable a HTTPS binding for the site. Start the "Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager". Right-click on the site and select "Edit bindings...". Add a binding of the "https" type. The HTTPS protocol should be bound to port 443.

  3. Enable SSL for each folder containing sensitive pages. Start the "Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager". Navigate the folders with sensitive pages. Double-click on the SSL icon in the right pane and enable SSL for the folder.
